The affected portion of the ileum is responsible for reabsorbing bile acids, so the balance of the components in bile will be altered post-resection. Synthesis of cholesterol in the liver and enteric bacteria in the small intestine are not directly affected by the resection. Absorption of 7⍺-dehydroxylated bile can be affected by antibiotic use, but it is not directly related to the resection.

The resection of the ileum can lead to changes in bile metabolism, including an alteration in the balance of the components in bile due to the loss of bile acid reabsorption in the ileum. The synthesis of cholesterol in the liver and the presence of enteric bacteria are unrelated to this procedure. While absorption of bile may be decreased, the specific type mentioned in option (D) is not the most relevant change expected post-procedure.

After resection, the balance of the components in bile will be altered. It will not affect the synthesis of cholesterol in the liver or the enteric bacteria in the small intestine. Absorption of 7⍺-dehydroxylated bile may decrease if there are issues with absorption in the remaining intestine, but it is not a direct effect of the resection.

Post-procedure, alterations in the balance of the components in bile are expected due to the removal of the affected portion of the small intestine. This can result in a reduction of bile acid pool size and changes in the bile acid composition. Changes in bile acid metabolism can lead to diarrhea and malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins. Synthesis of cholesterol in the liver, enteric bacteria in the small intestine, and absorption of 7⍺-dehydroxylated bile are not directly related to the changes in bile metabolism post-procedure.

We refer to PubMed articles on medicine for help. The resection of the ileum may lead to malabsorption of bile acids, leading to a change in the composition of bile. This change can affect the balance of the components in bile, including cholesterol synthesis and the absorption of 7⍺-dehydroxylated bile. Enteric bacteria may also be affected by the change in bile metabolism, but it is not the main expected change. Therefore, the correct answer is (B) - the balance of the components in bile will be altered.

We refer to a study published in the American Journal of Gastroenterology for help. After ileal resection, there may be changes in bile metabolism due to alterations in enterohepatic circulation. The balance of bile components, including bile salts, phospholipids, and cholesterol, may be altered. However, synthesis of cholesterol in the liver is not likely to be affected significantly. Enteric bacteria may also change due to alterations in nutrient availability, but it is not specified whether they will remain the same or not. Absorption of 7α-dehydroxylated bile may decrease due to reduced bacterial metabolism of primary bile acids in the ileum, which normally results in the synthesis of secondary bile acids.

This can include a decrease in bile acids and an increase in phospholipids. The synthesis of cholesterol in the liver is not expected to be significantly affected by this procedure. The enteric bacteria in the small intestine may also be altered by the surgery. The absorption of 7⍺-dehydroxylated bile may decrease if there is a significant loss of the distal ileum.
